Niger State Task Force on Covid-19 and the Secretary of the Government stated that as of April 29th, everyone, even those eligible to cross, into the State will be examined and screened thoroughly by medical personnel.

description: Niger continued to carry out a few special and humanitarian flights since the start of June. The protocol included: hand and baggage disinfection, temperature control, containment and testing (for some) of 2,977 passengers since the airports closed. As of June 26th, on the special flights, 68 people were detected positive and taken care of and their contacts were also confined.

description: Niger is planning on launching a country-wide food and cash distribution operation for all the families affected by the restrictions on the Transport sector. This operation will concern 4,054 households, or 28,376 beneficiary people, over a period of five months, starting May 5th.
type_text: The policy refers to the economical aspect of the country and isn't related to restrictions on sectors or lockdowns. This policy has to do with the financial relief policies that Niger is beginning to implement on specific groups of people.

description: Niger's government is increasing their 2020 general state budget from 2.266.15 billion to 2.405.53 billion, an increase of 139.38 billion, corresponding to 6.15%, due to Covid-19’s negative socio-economic consequences. This was announced on May 8, 2020 and is effective immediately.
type_text: This policy has to do with the national economic relief policies in terms of monetary value.

description: Nigeria is announcing the closure of all Bars, nightclubs, cinemas and places of entertainment  from March 18th onward
Nigeria is announcing the closure of all Bars, nightclubs, cinemas and places of entertainment  from March 18th onward
Niger has banned all gatherings with at least 1,000 people
Nigeria announced the ban of all groups of 50 persons or more from March 18th

Niger prohibits public gatherings, especially at weddings, baptisms, foyandi and funerals. It welcomes and supports the decision taken by the Religious Leaders (Ulemas and Christians) March 19 to ban collective prayers and the closure of places of worship, March 20
Niger announced the end of closure of places of worship and reopened them since May 13, 2020. The end date was not originally stated at the start of the policy.
Niger welcomes and supports the decision taken by the Religious Leaders (Ulemas and Christians), in particular, the ban on collective prayers and the closure of places of worship, 19 March.
Niger announced that a distance of at least one meter must be observed from March 18th onward
Niger: the capital Niamey is requiring people to wear face masks in all urban transport, in markets, supermarkets, shops, public squares of the capital from April 11
Niger announced that all citizens should wear masks April 22
